â€œWithin a kind of freer existenceâ€: MUSE Interviews Lilien Rosarian

06/10/2022

Kyle Boulton discusses nature, creativity, and the album format with one of ambient musicâ€™s most exciting prospects

Image by lilien rosarian, Bandcamp

By Lawrence Mason

â€œI don't think I wanted it to feel particularly natural or unnatural, just something in between, within a kind of freer existence.â€

â€œyour eyes can wanderâ€¦â€ reads the description to lilien rosarianâ€™s recent album, every flower in my garden (2022). Along with our eyes, nose, and all other sensory organs, we are then immersed in an overgrown â€œcolonyâ€ abundant with flora and tactile signifiers.

The day begins, the panoramic sun greets us like an old friend, and we are again reminded of our corporeality. Such is the opening track, â€˜iâ€™m wide awake!â€™, where a wave of visceral noise commences the listenerâ€™s journey.

The moment forms a reminder, a reminder that all we deem â€œnaturalâ€ and somehow separate is in fact an extension of ourselves. We, like the ecology around us, are a self-regulating system prone to malfunction, nourished through the surrounding world.

The garden we navigate is both soundscape and tactile representation, a space that is inextricable from the listenerâ€™s memories, experiences, and fears.

The subjectivity of these emotions entails a certain inadequacy when describing lilienâ€™s work, for her music is defined by a genre-fluid distortion of binaries; digital and natural, visceral and meditative. Worlds collide, forming a new space in which refuge is found.

In particular, every flower builds upon a (post)-pandemic plane of existence, when our time was and is increasingly divided between cyberspace and beauty spots once neglected. The sight of daffodils, the scent of lavender, or the gentle movement of grass, form different components of hyperreality. Yet, lilienâ€™s music is a reminder that these two ecosystems are more alike than not; worlds within worlds, existing within an eternal state of flux.

I spoke to lilien to better understand how the natural world has inspired her music. While ambient music is no stranger to environmental aesthetics, both a day in bel bruit (2019) and every flower in my garden offer something new - a glitchy fusion of alternative worlds, stitched together through lost loops, broken tapes and reminiscing thoughts.

First of all, thank you for speaking with MUSE. Iâ€™ll start with a simple question: whatâ€™s been inspiring you creatively recently?

Musically, I have a couple that come to mind: Alexander Schubert, and primarily his album Plays Sinebag (2011), which is such a playful collage of sounds which makes a mood I often try to live near.

The other is /f, one of my favourite artists who makes some of the most beautiful music I've heard despite being so otherworldly and complex at times. Particularly the way she seems to be able to make percussion from pretty much anything, and have it melded into everything else is something I really adore.

I also played The Witness (2016) recently, a puzzle game I really love. There's frequent moments of realising almost every aspect of your surroundings is intentional, yet it never really urges you to do anything, or even seems to care whether or not you noticed. It feels like a museum more than a game to me. I think a lot of my favourite music is like a puzzle, something that will challenge you to understand it, until you can internalise its patterns- thatâ€™s something I think about with my music often.

Iâ€™ve definitely noticed that dynamic in the fluidity of your music both sonically and thematically. Yet, there are underlying concepts that frame the music.

The most important aspect is that it gives me something to work towards. The themes are there because it helps give it more of an intention for its existence.Â  I think I've preferred releasing albums so far because itâ€™s just very satisfying to put all my effort toward a unified thing, so it ends up being a more meaningful project for me.

And how is it that youâ€™d describe your music? Are categories useful when doing so?

Categories / genres are certainly useful to some degree, though maybe not so relevant while I'm making the music. The main thing is having a feeling of what I want to make and if the sounds fit in the environment I'm going for.

As far as genres I really only wanted to make sure the collage aspect was consistent, and I didn't really worry about fitting into anything else. I think that tape experimentation + 'glitch' ambient are definitely consistent across my music, and I'm happy to embrace that but they aren't categories I'm really tied to, it's mostly just because I like the sounds a lot!

One notable feature of your music is how personal it sounds despite the absence of vocals beyond snippets of dialogue. To what extent is your music an exercise in abstract thought?

It reminds me of something I've been trying to do lately, more specifically on my last album, of making elements more 'directly' obscured. I wanted the samples to feel cut-and-pasted, so it sounds more tangible. There's rarely slow fade in / outs so many of the changes are more easily perceived, and I often avoid reverb-y, washed out sounding parts in favour of more tickly, close-up sounds. I feel like it helps give the feeling of clarity, like you don't have to squint your eyes anymore.

That's something I tried to do in the cover as well, which is a collage of edited photos. The pixelated artwork wasn't really done because I was interested in making pixel art, it's more so because I found that downsampling these really fuzzy screenshots would force me to fill in the blanks and see new things in them, which I liked a lot. I hope a similar kind of experience comes across in the music as well.

I definitely think the artwork for every flower does a wonderful job encapsulating your sound. Thinking about it, it seems that between the natural environment and its convergence with cyberspace, the human subject(s) of your music potentially disrupt their synthesis. Yet, a day in bel bruit concludes with the resurgence of human voices, promising â€œitâ€™ll be okayâ€. Does the human subject of your music disrupt the soundscapes you conjure, or do they occupy a more harmonious role?

Iâ€™d like to think it is harmonious, though I guess that is not up to me whether or not I did it successfully. For bel bruit, I tried to ensure all the voices were not happening in the environment, but through radio transmission, since the idea was that you're actually alone the whole time - I intended for the last track to be an outlier, as I interpret it as happening in your mind, while asleep. For every flower, I didn't really want any phrases / sentences to be too prevalent. I became very drawn to cutting up phrases and letting them become rhythms, which makes looping them work better..

I just really like the idea of there being many captured moments that appear as fragmented memories, where the context is removed but the feeling is still there. There are people posing for a photo and realising it's a video, (several) people giving tours of their home gardens, someone's school project on how to tie your shoes, kids interviewing their friends during school..to name a few. It feels satisfying to me to put all those pieces together, even if their origins can be completely unrecognisable.

Interesting. This brings me to my next question. Do you see your music as protective of the natural world, or reflective of it?

I would say it's protective in the sense of cherishing nature, and very friendly with it. For every flower, I especially tried not to make it reflective in the sense that I didn't want the concept (essentially walking through a garden) to be so literal and instead feel like heightened reality, noticing details you couldn't see before.. I don't think I wanted it to feel particularly natural or unnatural, just something in between, within a kind of freer existence.

Beautifully put. To conclude, what can we expect from you in the future? Is making music financially sustainable or is it a side gig for now?

I'm trying to figure it out! I'd like to do something fairly different, but I'm not sure what that would end up being. I learned a lot after making the first album (a day in bel bruit) and I'm actually really happy with how I progressed with the second one, the result ended up being a lot more of what I intended it to be. For now I'm just doing more experimenting and seeing where it takes me.

Making music is definitely not financially sustainable for me, but I'm happy anyone at all has supported my music so far, it's way more than I could have imagined. I'm not so concerned with sustaining myself through music since I realise where I'm realistically likely to go with it is pretty niche all in all, but I'm ok with that!

Thank you again for taking the time to speak with MUSE!

Thank you for asking me to do this! I really appreciate it :) - Amy

Editorâ€™s Note: This interview was conducted through Twitter Direct Message. Lilienâ€™s discography is available across streaming platforms including Bandcamp, Spotify, Apple Music, and YouTube.
